3476.name: Vitamin A supplementation coverage rate (% of children ages 6-59 months)
3476.description: Vitamin A supplementation refers to the percentage of children ages 6-59 months old who received at least two doses of vitamin A in the previous year.
3476.s_name: World Bank – WDI: Vitamin A supplementation coverage rate (% of children ages 6-59 months)

source.name: World Bank – WDI: Vitamin A supplementation coverage rate (% of children ages 6-59 months)
source.dataPublisherSource: United Nations Children's Fund, State of the World's Children.
source.additionalInfo: General comments: Vitamin A is essential for optimal functioning of the immune system. Vitamin A deficiency, a leading cause of blindness, also causes a greater risk of dying from a range of childhood ailments such as measles, malaria, and diarrhea. In low- and middle-income countries, where vitamin A is consumed largely in fruits and vegetables, daily per capita intake is often insufficient to meet dietary requirements. Providing young children with two high-dose vitamin A capsules a year is a safe, cost-effective, efficient strategy for eliminating vitamin A deficiency and improving child survival. Giving vitamin A to new breastfeeding mothers helps protect their children during the first few months of life. Food fortification with vitamin A is being introduced in many developing countries.
